facts.text: Prosecution sanctioned by Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: prosecution has been sanctioned by the Government of India. In December, 1962, he was serving as Superintendent of Police and was selected to be Commandant of 8th Batallion of Rajastha

facts.text: Petitioner serving as Superintendent of Police in December 1962 and selected to be Commandant of 8th Battalion of Rajasthan Armed Constabulary.

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1962, he was serving as Superintendent of Police and was selected to be Commandant of 8th Batallion of Rajasthan Armed Constabulary. He avers that he took over as Commandant

facts.text: Petitioner took over as Commandant on January 7, 1963 but placed under suspension the same day.

anchor.surface_text: He avers that he took over as Commandant on January 7, 1963 but was placed under suspension the same day and a case was registered on January 12, 1963 which has resulted in the present

facts.text: Case registered on January 12, 1963 leading to present prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: the same day and a case was registered on January 12, 1963 which has resulted in the present prosecution against him. The petitioner apprehends for reasons to be stated presently that he

facts.text: Petitioner apprehends no fair trial in Rajasthan due to hostility of then Law Minister (also in charge of Home Department), Additional Inspector General of Police Anti-Corruption, and Deputy Inspector General of Police Ajmer Range.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner apprehends for reasons to be stated presently that he is number likely to get a fair, just and impartial trial in the State of Rajasthan owing to the hostility and influence of the then Law Minister who was also Minister incharge of Home Department of the State, the Additional Inspector General of Police, Anti-Corruption, and the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Ajmer Range, Jaipur.

facts.text: State Government opposed the transfer application and questioned jurisdiction of Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government has opposed the application strenu. ously and has questioned the jurisdiction of this Court to transfer under the powers companyferred on it by s 527 Code of Criminal Procedure a case made over by the Government of the State of Rajasthan for trial to a Special Judge under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952  Act 46 of 1962 .

facts.text: While transfer petition pending, State Government served petitioner with notice and charge-sheet for breach of Rule No. 8 of All India Services Conduct Rules, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: While this petition was pending the State Government served the petitioner with a numberice and a charge-sheet to show cause why he should number be proceeded against for breach of Rule No. 8 of the All India Services  Conduct  Rules, 1954, because he had companymunicated directly indirectly official documents and information to Government servants other persons to whom he was number authorised to companymunicate such documents information as indicated and detailed in a statement of allegations accompanying the numberice and the charge.

facts.text: Charge related to petitioner communicating 31 and 16 documents to his counsel R.K. Rastogi and D.P. Gupta and others in writ petition No. 794 of 1964 in Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government has appended to this charge two appendices giving details of 31 and 16 docu- ments respectively, which were said to have been so companymunicated by the petitioner to his companynsel Messrs. R. K. Rastogi and D. P. Gupta, Advocates of Jodhpur and others named as number-petitioners in a writ petition which he had filed in the High Court of Rajasthan  No. 794 of 1964  and which he subsequently withdrew on December 23, 1964 before taking action to file the present petition.

facts.text: Writ petition No. 794 of 1964 filed by petitioner in Rajasthan High Court withdrawn on December 23, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: a writ petition which he had filed in the High Court of Rajasthan  No. 794 of 1964  and which he subsequently withdrew on December 23, 1964 before taking action to file the present petition. The numberice, the charge and the statement of allegations accompanying them were signed by Mr. Vishnu Dutt Sharma, Special Secretary to Government.

facts.text: Notice and charge signed by Mr. Vishnu Dutt Sharma, Special Secretary to Government.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice, the charge and the statement of allegations accompanying them were signed by Mr. Vishnu Dutt Sharma, Special Secretary to Government. On receiving this charge, the petitioner moved another petition in this Court for taking action against Mr. Shrama and the Government of Rajasthan for companytempt of this Court.

facts.text: Petitioner filed contempt petition against Mr. Sharma and Government of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving this charge, the petitioner moved another petition in this Court for taking action against Mr. Shrama and the Government of Rajasthan for companytempt of this Court. At an earlier hearing, where we were companysidering the petition for transfer, the other petition was brought to our numberice and we were about to order issuance of numberices to the companytemners but the Advocate General of the Government of Rajasthan took numberice of the petition and offered to take action in respect thereof.

facts.text: State of Rajasthan through Chief Secretary and Mr. Sharma filed replies to contempt petition.

anchor.surface_text: As a result the State of Rajasthan through the Chief Secretary to the Government and Mr. Sharma separately filed their replies to the second petition and attempted justification. Mr. Sharma abjured knowledge of the companytents of the petition for transfer and denied any malice, ill-will or grudge, pleading good faith.

facts.text: State Government and Mr. Sharma tendered unconditional apology for contempt, which was accepted by court.

anchor.surface_text: The matter would have received serious attention from us but for the fact that at the next hearing the plea for justification was abandoned and an unconditional apology was entered on behalf of the State Government as well as Mr. Sharma. The latter was present in Court and expressed regret for what had. happened. We accepted the appology and do number, therefore,feel called upon to companysider the plea of justification which, in any event, is number a plea heard in bar when companytempt is clear and manifest.

facts.text: Court found that charging petitioner amounted to indirect pressure on his transfer petition.

anchor.surface_text: There companyld be numberquestion in the present case that by charging the petitioner with proceedings of a different kind there was, if number direct, at least indirect pressure brought upon him in the prosecution of his petition for. transfer. Of this we would have taken serious numbere be- cause it was likely to have hampered the petitioner in prosecuting his petition freely before this Court and would have resulted in obstruction of administration of justice.

facts.text: Court holds it has jurisdiction under S.527 CrPC to transfer case from one Special Judge to another subordinate to different High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the Supreme Court in exercise of its jurisdiction and power under s. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can transfer a case from a special Judge subordinate to one High Court to another special Judge subordinate to another High Court. This brings us to the question of the merits of the petition.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges hostility from State Government by downgrading his post as Commandant.

anchor.surface_text: In relation to the State Government he has alleged that when he was appointed Commandant of the 8th Battallion of Rajasthan Armed Constabulary the State Government down-graded his post, otherwise he would have received a higher starting pay. He also alleges that his suspension and prosecution were made to companyncide With his assumption of new duties so that he might number be able to join his new post.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges five instances of crossing path with Home Minister Mr. Mathura Dass Mathur.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the Home Minister the petitioner has given five instances in which he apparently crossed the ministers path and gave him room for annoyance. In regard to the two Police Officers he has averred that the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Ajmer Range  Hanuman Prasad Sharma  and he had some differences on three occasions.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges differences with DIG Ajmer Range Hanuman Prasad Sharma on three occasions and with Sultan Singh DIG.

anchor.surface_text: He has also given similar instances of hostility towards him entertained by Sultan Singh, Deputy Inspector General of Police. On the basis of these he says that he entertains an apprehension that he will number receive justice in the State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Court finds petitioner's apprehension of no fair trial not reasonable, no material of interference with trial.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles it may be said that there is a possibility that the petitioner entertains an apprehension that certain persons are hostile to him but his apprehension that he will number receive justice in the State of Rajasthan is number in our opinion reasonable. All the facts which he has narrated bear upon past events in his official life.

facts.text: Court declines to order transfer of the case.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter we decline to order trans- fer of the case from the special Judge, Bharatpur.
Under Section 527 of Criminal Procedure Code . R. Bhasin, for the petitioner. C. Kasliwal, Advocate-General for the State of Rajasthan, K. Jain and R. N. Sachthey for the Respondent.

arguments.claim: Case assigned to special Judge under 1952 Act cannot be transferred as Act is self-contained special law requiring trial by designated special Judge only

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded by the Advocate General that the power to transfer criminal cases as laid down in the section is ordinarily available but he contends that a case assigned by the State Government under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 to a special Judge cannot be transferred at all because under the terms of that Act, which is a self-contained special law, such a case must be tried by the special Judge designate only.

arguments.claim: Supreme Court has jurisdiction under s.527 CrPC to transfer from one special Judge to another

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the Supreme Court in exercise of its jurisdiction and power under s. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can transfer a case from a special Judge subordinate to one High Court to another special Judge subordinate to another High Court.

arguments.claim: No inconsistency between s.527 CrPC and s.7(2) Criminal Law Amendment Act

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, resolves itself to this is there an inconsistency between s. 527 of the Code and the second sub-section of s. 7 ? The answer is that there is none

arguments.claim: Transfer warranted only on reasonable apprehension of justice failure, not mere allegation

anchor.surface_text: The law with regard to transfer of cases is well-settled. A case is transferred if there is a reasonable apprehension on the part of a party to a case that justice will not be done. ... It is one of the principles of the administration of justice that justice should not only be done but it should be seen to be done.

arguments.claim: Charge proceedings should wait until transfer petition concludes to avoid pressure

anchor.surface_text: There could be no question in the present case that by charging the petitioner with proceedings of a different kind there was, if not direct, at least indirect pressure brought upon him in the prosecution of his petition for transfer. ... If the petitioner was guilty of any lapse under the Services Conduct Rules or even guilty of an offence the action to which he would be otherwise subject could wait till the present proceedings had terminated

holdings.text: the Supreme Court in exercise of its jurisdiction and power under s. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can transfer a case from a special Judge subordinate to one High Court to another special Judge subordinate to another High Court

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the Supreme Court in exercise of its jurisdiction and power under s. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can transfer a case from a special Judge subordinate to one High Court to another special Judge subordinate to another High Court. This brings us to the question of the merits of the petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7(2) CLAA territorial provision yields to CrPC transfer powers preserved by s.8(3) CLAA; no inconsistency as transfer creates jurisdiction; follows Ramchandra Prasad precedent

holdings.text: there is no inconsistency between s. 527 of the Code and the second sub-section of s. 7

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, resolves itself to this is there an inconsistency between s. 527 of the Code and the second sub-section of s. 7 ? The answer is that there is none Apparently this Court in the earlier case found no inconsistency

holdings.reasoning_summary: Territorial condition in s.7(2) CLAA specifies judge selection, not absolute bar; CrPC s.527 applies via s.8(3) CLAA without conflict

holdings.text: his apprehension that he will not receive justice in the State of Rajasthan is not in our opinion reasonable... we decline to order transfer of the case from the special Judge, Bharatpur

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles it may be said that there is a possibility that the petitioner entertains an apprehension that certain persons are hostile to him but his apprehension that he will not receive justice in the State of Rajasthan is not in our opinion reasonable. All the facts which he has narrated bear upon past events in his official life.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Past official hostilities insufficient without material showing interference with investigation or trial; apprehension must appear reasonable to court; applies settled transfer law

holdings.text: by charging the petitioner with proceedings of a different kind there was, if not direct, at least indirect pressure brought upon him in the prosecution of his petition for transfer... Such a course of action is to be deprecated... the action... could wait till the present proceedings had terminated

anchor.surface_text: There could be no question in the present case that by charging the petitioner with proceedings of a different kind there was, if not direct, at least indirect pressure brought upon him in the prosecution of his petition for. transfer. Of this we would have taken serious notice be- cause it was likely to have hampered the petitioner in prosecuting his petition freely before this Court and would have resulted in obstruction of administration of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Timing of charge-sheet during pendency hampers free prosecution of petition and obstructs justice; contempt clear but unconditional apology accepted, no further action; disciplinary action should await conclusion

precedents.citation: Ramchandra Prasad v. State of Bihar 1 [1962] 2 S.C.R. 50

anchor.surface_text: But this Court in Ramchandra Prasad v. State of Bihar 1 upheld the transfer of a case by the High Court which took it to a special Judge who had numberjurisdiction in the area where the offence was companymitted. In holding that the transfer was valid this Court relied upon the third sub-section of s. 8 of the Act. That sub-section preserves the application of any provision of the Code of Criminal Procedure if it is number inconsistent with the Act, save as provided in the first two sub-sections of that section. The question, therefore, resolves itself to this is there an inconsistency between s. 527 of the Code and the second sub-section of s. 7 ? The answer is that there is numbere Apparently this Court in the earlier case found numberinconsistency and the reasons appear to be these The companydition that an offence specified in s. 6 2  shall be tried by a special Judge for the area within which it is companymitted merely specifies which of several special Judges appointed in the State by the State Government shall try it. The 1 1962 2 S.C.R. 50.

precedents.case_name: Ramchandra Prasad v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Transfer of a case to a special Judge lacking territorial jurisdiction under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 is valid, as s.8(3) preserves provisions of CrPC not inconsistent with the Act, and there is no inconsistency with s.7(2)
precedents.cited_holding: held that the transfer was valid relying on s.8(3) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the Supreme Court in exercise of its jurisdiction and power under s. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can transfer a case from a special Judge subordinate to one High Court to another special Judge subordinate to another High Court. This brings us to the question of the merits of the petition.
In this view of the matter we decline to order trans- fer of the case from the special Judge, Bharatpur.

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, resolves itself to this is there an inconsistency between s. 527 of the Code and the second sub-section of s. 7 ? The answer is that there is none Apparently this Court in the earlier case found no inconsistency
In this view of the matter we decline to order trans- fer of the case from the special Judge, Bharatpur.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles it may be said that there is a possibility that the petitioner entertains an apprehension that certain persons are hostile to him but his apprehension that he will not receive justice in the State of Rajasthan is not in our opinion reasonable. All the facts which he has narrated bear upon past events in his official life.
In this view of the matter we decline to order trans- fer of the case from the special Judge, Bharatpur.
m were signed by Mr. Vishnu Dutt Sharma, Special Secretary to Government. On receiving this charge, the petitioner moved another petition in this Cour

edges.explanation: Holding on indirect pressure from charging addresses the core issue of contempt.

anchor.surface_text: There could be no question in the present case that by charging the petitioner with proceedings of a different kind there was, if not direct, at least indirect pressure brought upon him in the prosecution of his petition for. transfer. Of this we would have taken serious notice be- cause it was likely to have hampered the petitioner in prosecuting his petition freely before this Court and would have resulted in obstruction of administration of justice.
